newsitem.title: AFGHANISTAN: Dostum holds Taleban at bay in Afghan mountains.
newsitem.headline: Dostum holds Taleban at bay in Afghan mountains.

text.p: Afghan fighters wearing a motley array of ex-Soviet army surplus, long shirts and turbans blew on their hands as freezing cloud poured down off the peaks of the Hindu Kush mountains on Wednesday.
Members of Afghan warlord General Abdul Rashid Dostum's Jumbash faction, the fighters were guarding a road tunnel on the strategically vital salang highway.
Dostum's men and armour moved onto the pass to forestall an advance northwards by the radical Islamic Taleban militia which seized the capital Kabul last week.

The tunnel, 70 km (45 miles) northwest of Kabul and abandoned by deposed President Burhanuddin Rabbani's forces last week, forms a vital link between the capital, northern Afghanistan and the Central Asian republics beyond.
The mountainside bristled with Jumbash weaponry. Howitzers, mortars and tanks were dug in around the tunnel and the surrounding heights, over 3,000 meters (yards) above sea level.
A Grad multiple rocket launcher had its barrels trained down the valley, with rice fields and mulberry trees visible in the distance.

"The Taleban are down there," said the frontline commander, Colonel-General Chary, in a long corduory shirt and hefty turban to keep out the cold, his outstretched hand following the line of the rocket launcher.
"We command the heights -- there has been no fighting here," he said.
Dostum's Jumbash faction, or the National Islamic Movement of Afghanistan, has said it does not want to fight the Taleban.
But the armour guarding the spectacular natural gate to Dostum's northern territory gave a clear message.
"We don't want to fight but we will defend ourselves,' the front commander said.
The Taleban's lightning advance northwards, bringing with it its fundamentalist brand of Islam, sent shivers through the relatively liberal northern territories controlled by Dostum.

But the charred, wrecked tanks littering the Salang highway, remnants of the ill-fated Soviet intervention from 1979-1989 and later inter-faction fighting, are an awesome reminder of the cost of taking the road.
The snows, due soon, will make an advance across the pass extremely difficult.
Winter jackets were handed round to Dostum's men, some without socks, in anticipation.
"So far the Taleban have taken towns without any serious fighting," said a western aid worker based in the region.
He questioned the militia's ability to scrap with Dostum's well-armed and well-disciplined forces.
Buses and trucks full of refugees, piled high with bags and bicycles, teetered over the pass away from Kabul to find sanctuary in Dostum's lands.

Colonel Sayed Ahmed, a bearded Afghan commander at the front -- Jumbash fighters sport only moustaches -- said he had abandoned Rabbani's army and joined the Jumbash to hold back the Taleban. "The Taleban are bad people," he said.
A truck load of Rabbani's soldiers drew up behind the colonel's jeep, also intent on changing sides.
But despite diverse protestations of support for Dostum, including that of Russian security tsar and Afghan veteran Alexander Lebed, the wily general cannot rest easy.
There is widespread talk of more war.
"The Taleban want all Afghanistan," said another aid worker who declined to be named.
